title: 104_hr3476
content: The Act is titled the "College Campus Alcohol Abuse Prevention and Education Act". It focuses on higher education and drug and alcohol abuse prevention. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include prohibitions on promoting alcohol consumption on campus, distributing free alcoholic beverages for promotional purposes, and sponsoring on-campus events by alcoholic beverage companies. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include restrictions on alcohol advertising in college publications, protection of students and employees seeking help for alcohol-related issues, and the requirement for student and employee involvement in developing policies. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a waiver of sanctions for institutions of higher education developing and implementing required plans. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a waiver of sanctions for institutions of higher education developing and implementing required plans. Grants and contracts are addressed in Section 3. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Secretary to provide grants and contracts to institutions of higher education for programs aimed at preventing drug and alcohol abuse and associated violence. Grants and contracts can also support a higher education center for alcohol and drug abuse prevention. The Secretary will award grants and contracts to institutions of higher education on a competitive basis. Applications must be submitted with required information. Efforts will be made to ensure fair participation of all types of institutions and geographic locations. Preference will be given to institutions with limited enrollment. Repeal of Section 4122 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, which pertains to institutions of higher education with limited enrollment. SEC. 4. NATIONAL RECOGNITION AWARDS. The Secretary of Education annually awards 10 National Recognition Awards to higher education institutions with effective alcohol and drug abuse prevention programs. Recipients are honored in Washington, D.C., and their programs are nationally recognized. Applications must include clear goals and objectives. The National Recognition Awards are given annually by the Secretary of Education to higher education institutions with effective alcohol and drug abuse prevention programs. Applications must include clear goals and objectives, program activities focusing on policy issues, student and employee participation, criteria for effectiveness evaluation, and special initiatives. The National Recognition Awards are given annually by the Secretary of Education to higher education institutions with effective alcohol and drug abuse prevention programs. Eligible institutions must have established prevention and education programs, and nominations can be self-nominated or nominated by others. Special initiatives, coordination efforts, and networking in the community are also important criteria for consideration. The Secretary of Education appoints a committee to review applications for the National Recognition Awards for effective alcohol and drug abuse prevention programs in higher education. The committee includes representatives from various departments and agencies, professional associations, and non-Federal scientists. Review criteria are developed by the Secretary in conjunction with appropriate stakeholders. The committee reviews applications for National Recognition Awards for alcohol and drug abuse prevention programs in higher education. Criteria include effectiveness measures like changes in campus environment and program institutionalization assessments. Authorization is provided for the awards program under this section with specified amounts for fiscal years 1996 to 2002.
